abstract.p: Customer rage is a complex phenomenon that is beginning to receive attention from researchers and practitioners. To date, research into the phenomenon has focused exclusively on its occurrence within a failed service context; however, rage may also occur in nonfailure situations as a negative by-product of an organization’s efforts to engage the customer at an emotional level. As a service entity, the live sporting event is characterized by a number of features which make it particularly susceptible to acts of rage. This article examines rage within the context of spectator sport by utilizing a framework that is capable of organizing and focusing attention upon those factors that shape a fan’s consumption experience and render spectator sport, and services in general, susceptible to rage. Services marketers may be unable to eliminate all incidents of spectator rage, especially those that arise when a customer becomes excessively and emotionally absorbed with the service encounter. Nevertheless, fans’ propensity to rage may be reduced by understanding the factors that contribute to it and by carefully designing servicescapes and vigilantly managing customer interactions to generate exhilarating, yet nonaggressive, customer experiences.

body.p: Incidents of customer rage have become more prevalent in recent years (Grainer 2004; McColl-Kennedy et al. 2009; Shellenbarger 2010), yet relatively little is known about the phenomenon or how to diffuse it. Extant research documents its existence and focus attention on rage incidents related to service failures (e.g., Grove, Fisk, and John 2004; Kalamas, Laroche, and Makdessian 2008; McColl-Kennedy et al. 2009). However, rage may also occur in situations when service delivery does not fail, for example, when a restaurant employee refuses to serve lunch during breakfast hours (Schellenbarger 2010). Such occurrences are perhaps even more perplexing than rage incidents linked to service delivery breakdowns. The limited understanding of customer rage, including is antecedents and consequences, make most companies ill-equipped to manage this potentially dangerous phenomenon (Grove, Fisk, and John 2004; McColl-Kennedy et al. 2009).

We propose that customer rage emerges as an undesirable by-product of customer engagement in the service. Through customer engagement, patrons cocreate customer value (Lusch and Vargo 2006) that customizes (van Doorn et al. 2010) and personalizes (Prahalad and Ramaswamy 2000) the customer-to-brand experience. Consequently, even if the service performance is flawless, customer rage can still arise from an unfavorable experience resulting from customer- or context-related factors. Whereas research examines rage as a consequence of service failure, less is known about its occurrence within service contexts designed to engage customers at an emotional level.

Spectator sport is multisensory phenomenon that evokes a range of emotional responses, including rage (Hirschman and Holbrook 1982, King, Kahle, and Close 2011). As such, rage at sporting events has been examined in various disciplines; however, it has received relatively little attention by marketers (Hunt, Bristol, and Bashaw 1999). This is unfortunate since fan rage has potentially significant implications for sport marketers, both financially and socially. To gain an understanding of both customer and spectator rage, we examine rage as a negative by-product of an emotionally engaged customer. Specifically, our study addresses the following research questions: What factors contribute to the occurrence of spectator rage, even when the service itself (i.e., the sporting event) is performed flawlessly and what are the implications associated with these factors for enhancing the understanding customer rage within services, in general? By examining the incidences of customer rage within the context of spectator sport, we contribute to the rage literature by introducing a framework that illuminates the complexity of the phenomenon by depicting factors and dynamics that characterize spectator rage specifically and customer range in general. We also shed light on the diversity of controllable and uncontrollable factors that may prompt rage across service industries, whether it is triggered by service failure or other dynamics.

In the following sections, we establish that customer rage may arise as a negative by-product within the emotionally engaging service context of spectator sport and propose a model of spectator rage based on an existing customer rage framework. Research propositions associated with the framework are provided, as are theoretical and managerial implications for spectator sport and services, in general.

sec.title: Spectator Sport as a Service Business
sec.p: A customer’s role in the cocreation of value is unmistakable in spectator sport (cf. Greyser 2011) where the live sporting event is the primary product of the sport industry, with various other products (i.e., licensing agreements, broadcast rights, and sponsor relationships) contingent on it (Mullin, Hardy, and Sutton 2000). While the size of the spectator sport industry is difficult to accurately estimate, one source states that spectator spending (e.g., ticket sales, concessions, and travel) in the United States is approximately $26 billion ( Street and Smith’s Sport Business Journal 2002). In 2009, about 75 million people attended a regular season Major League Baseball game and 17 million spectators attended a regular season National Football League (NFL) contest (ESPN.go.com 2010). Clearly, any circumstance such as the occurrence of customer rage that undermines the attractiveness of sporting contests may have deleterious consequences for various stakeholders.

Spectator sport is a service industry in which a set of intangible actions are directed at consumer’ minds (Lovelock 1983). Even though spectator sport does not readily lend itself to customization (Lovelock 1983), fans are increasingly interested in personalizing their experiences just as customers are with any good or service (Prahalad and Ramaswamy 2000). Companies that successfully engage and emotionally satisfy customers tend to be rewarded with superlative outcomes in terms of top-line and bottom-line performance and relationship growth (Fleming, Coffman, and Harter 2005). The importance and predominance of customer engagement in spectator sport has led to claims that fans represent the heart and soul of sport and sport properties (Greyser 2011); that sport fans differ from other types of customers in the magnitude of emotion and depth of affiliation that characterizes their sporting experiences (King, Kahle, and Close 2011); and, that the interactive aspect of fan experiences is a key driver of service quality with respect to spectator sport (Ko et al. 2011).

Like services, in general, spectator sporting events are comprised of four key components that combine to create a service encounter: a setting (the sport venue), employees (the athletes and the venue staff), the service performance (the athletic contest and all of the facets of its staging within the venue), and customers (the spectators). Each of these has the potential to impact spectators’ experience and perception of excellence (Fisk, Grove, and John 2008; Langeard et al. 1981). In this study, we use the terms spectator or fan interchangeably to identify an individual who is physically present at a live sporting event (Wenner and Gantz 1998).

sec.title: Customer Rage and Spectator Rage: An Overview Customer Rage
sec.p: Customer rage is a strong negative and antisocial emotion, an intense anger that manifests itself in numerous ways, including verbal, physical, nonverbal, and displaced aggression (Deffenbacher et al. 2002; McColl-Kennedy et al. 2009). Some argue that rage is distinguished from other forms of anger because it is a stronger or more pronounced emotion (Kalamas, Laroche, and Makdessian 2007). Consistent with this conceptualization, we use the term rage to broadly represent a behavioral response that is intensely negative, antisocial, and displays hostility, ferocity, hate, and the like. Hence, customer rage consists of an affective state and a behavioral response. The former involves the fore mentioned negative, antisocial emotions, while the latter typically represents the overt expression of those emotions (McColl-Kennedy et al. 2009) as a means of coping and relieving stress (Lazarus and Folkman 1984). Feelings of hostility, while deleterious in their own right, are not rage until those feelings lead to actions. Rage may occur in three types of situations (Shaver et al 1987): when something interferes with a person’s execution of plans or attainment of personal goals; when one believes that he or she is being harmed, physically or psychologically, by another; or, when one feels that behavioral interference being experienced is illegitimate and contrary to what ought to be.

sec.title: Customer Rage and Services
sec.p: Customer rage is commonly found in the service sector (Grove, Fisk, and John 2004; McColl-Kennedy and Smith 2006) and any of the four components of a service encounter—the workers, the service process, the setting, or the assembly of customers (Fisk, Grove, and John 2008)—may prompt it. The creation and delivery of services in real time, combined with both a potentially large number of service inputs that are difficult to control and the limited ability to personalize the service, increases the likelihood and magnitude of an unfavorable customer service experience (Fisk, Grove, and John 2008; Lovelock and Wirtz 2011) that may ultimately result in rage (cf. Bougie, Pieters, and Zeelenberg 2003; Smith and Bolton 2002).

Rage is one of many forms of dysfunctional customer behavior that can occur during service delivery (Fisk et al. 2010; Fullerton and Punj 1993; Harris and Reynolds 2004). When it does arise, a service patron may become an unwelcomed “jaycustomer” (Lovelock 1994), a customer who acts in a thoughtless or abusive manner, creating problems for employees, other customers and the firm (Harris and Reynolds 2004). The actions of a raging customer (e.g., yelling, vandalizing, physical assault, etc.) are often disruptive and can undermine the service experience of all other parties involved. Clearly, service organizations would benefit by practices and policies that reduce the likelihood and/or impact of customer rage.

sec.title: Spectator Rage
sec.p: Consistent with rage’s conceptualization in other contexts, spectator rage refers to violent and uncontrolled acts of aggression (Coakley 1998). Moreover, the phenomenon of spectator rage is complex with roots and expression that are difficult to address due to its multifaceted nature. To help comprehend the phenomenon, we employ the broad 4-Ts framework (Grove, Fisk, and John 2004) to organize pertinent issues and provide insights. The framework represents a useful and logical tool, but in no way catalogues all of the specifics pertaining to the phenomenon due to the vast array of particulars pertaining to each of the key issues. Instead, the 4-Ts are offered as a structure to establish the efficacy of the framework to better understand spectator rage. In the following pages, we utilize the framework to investigate key issues related to fan rage and to offer research propositions resulting from our examination. Ultimately, insights gleaned from this activity are offered in terms of their implications for understanding customer rage in general.

sec.title: The “4-Ts” Framework for Understanding Spectator Rage
sec.p: The “4-Ts of Customer Rage” framework (Grove, Fisk, and John 2004) captures the complexity of customer rage and bring attention to services-related issues associated with it. The framework posits that customer rage may be understood by examining the interrelationships among four factors which relate broadly to dysfunctional behavior, in general (e.g., Fullerton and Punj 1993; Keeffe and Russell-Bennett 2006): the targets of consumer rage behavior; the temperament of customers that may predispose one to rage; the triggers that spark rage behavior; and, the treatments for addressing and rage’s occurrence. In this study, we adapt and apply the 4 -Ts framework to discern the unique aspects of rage associated with spectator sport and to develop insights pertaining to customer rage at large. While each of the Ts is addressed separately, it is important to recognize that the four factors may be intricately interrelated (see Figure 1 ).

sec.title: Targets
sec.p: Live sporting events are characterized by rich and complex interactions among customers (i.e., spectators) and service providers, usually within a well-defined service setting (e.g., stadium). Correspondingly, just as with customer rage in general, a fan who rages may direct his or her anger toward its source within the service context, displace it by transferring it to another object, or attempt to suppress it (cf. McColl-Kennedy et al. 2009; Shaver et al. 1987). With respect to the latter option, once anger is elicited, cognitive biases and physiological tendencies arise automatically unless one can suppress the emotion through self-control (Shaver et al. 1987). For example, enraged fans may seek to stem their anger by denying their feeling (e.g., telling themselves to get over it or to calm down) or restraining their tendencies to act on it. Unfortunately, an emotion often becomes public before one can successfully control it (Shaver et al. 1987). Hence, it is likely that an enraged fan will express his or her angst by directing or displacing it toward service participants (fans and employees/contestants), aspects of the service setting (stadium) or even the service performance (the athletic contest) itself (Fullerton and Punj 2004; Harris and Reynolds 2003; Lovelock 1994), rendering them the targets of fan rage.

As with many services (e.g., hotels and hospitals), the live sporting event typically offers its attendees multiple opportunities to interact with various venue employees that are responsible for creating the spectator experience. Whether they are concessionaires, ticket-takers, security personnel or other personnel, these frontline or boundary-spanning service workers (Bowen and Schneider 1985) are sometimes easy targets for raging fans. Clearly, that’s the case when such employees provoke fans by their actions (directed rage), yet they may also become targets due to causes for which they are not responsible (displaced rage). The upshot of this is that in the milieu of spectator sport, as in many service contexts, employees are sometimes in harm’s way for spectator rage.

Live sporting events also involve interaction—albeit relatively indirect—between spectators and those participating in a contest itself such as players, coaches, and officials. Indeed, the interaction between spectators and game participants (e.g., cheering, distracting an opponent with noise, shouting at an umpire or official, etc.) is a fundamental component of the spectator sport experience and often there is no separation between the athlete, the entertainment, and the fan (Shank 2002, p. 234). Unfortunately, some spectators who are displeased with the on-field performance, event outcome, or officiating may cross the line of civility and sling vulgarities at or, worse yet, physically accost the sport participants. For example, spectators attending the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing hurled debris (i.e., beer cans) on to the track and in the direction of the winning driver as a show of disfavor toward him (Ryan 2007). Sporting events also offer opportunity for substantial interaction among spectators. Fans at sporting events are often seated very close to one another—a circumstance that sometimes makes one a party to another’s unwelcome verbal and physical behavior. Innocent bystanders’ spectator experience can easily be ruined by others and prompt varied responses, including rage (Grove and Fisk 1997; Harris and Reynolds 2003). Even those not directly interacting with a raging fan but simply in his or her proximity may have their spectator experience disrupted or negatively impacted through a contagion effect (e.g., Martin and Pranter 1989; McColl-Kennedy and Smith 2006).

Furthermore, sporting events are typically attended by supporters of the opposing teams or athletes involved in the competition. Obviously, the ideal outcome of a contest may vary substantially based on which team or individual a spectator supports, and interactions among spectators may reflect this conflict of objectives. One or more fans may respond with verbal insults, ugly gestures, and violence toward their counterparts if they become upset with the nature of the contest or its result. When a larger collectivity of fans is involved, these actions on occasion can continue beyond the confines of the stadium or arena and spill out into the community where the public in general may be affected.

In services in general or spectator sport specifically, sometimes the target of an enraged customer’s actions is not another person or persons, but rather the physical setting for the event (Fullerton and Punj 2004; Harris and Reynolds 2004; McColl-Kennedy and Smith 2006). Whatever the cause of their anger, spectators have been known to strike out at their surroundings. Ripping seats apart, pounding partitions, marring walls, and damaging the landscape are common expressions of spectator fury. Occasionally, the fury is not rooted in anger but develops as a celebratory expression including traditions such as tearing down of football goal posts, storming the field of play and the like. Regardless, such acts reflect a vandalism response associated with jaycustomer behavior (Lovelock 1994) plague service organizations.

Finally, in some instances fans’ ire, particularly when it is a collective expression, can be directed at the athletic contest itself. Athletic contests, like service performances in general, are essentially processes that evolve within a set structure to reach a particular end, that is, declare a winner. When the actual performance deviates too far from the one desired by the fans, their disenchantment with the service performance may turn to intense anger or wrath that spawns sabotage (Harris and Ogbonna 2008) of the sporting event itself. Violent displays in the stands, unruly actions toward contestants, vandalism and sundry other displays of collective rage can bring a halt to an athletic contest before its conclusion in the name of safety and sanity. The postponement of Italian soccer matches under such circumstances has occurred (Sports Network 2007). When viewed in whole, it is apparent that any component of the service encounter (i.e., employees, customers, service setting, and process) associated with spectator sport (i.e., athletes/staff, fans, stadium, and contest) may become targets of spectator rage. Propositions 1 and 2 address the customer rage targets component depicted in Figure 1.
Proposition 1: Fans are more likely to engage in rage behavior when they are less skilled at suppressing a felt anger with some aspect of the sporting event.
Proposition 2: Fans are more likely to displace rage when they are (a) unable to identify or (b) unable to interact with, or (c) unwilling to direct their rage toward its source.

sec.title: Temperament
sec.p: A spectator’s (customer’s) temperament (i.e., personality and/or current state of mind) influences the likelihood that he or she may become enraged at a live sporting event. Spectator sport, like many services, involves an activity that is performed before a large number of customers simultaneously and it should be recognized that some in attendance may be prone to rage. In fact, some fans seem predisposed to rage and appear ready to “go off” with little provocation. For example, a person’s predisposition to rage may be influenced a number of physiological conditions, including low levels of serum cholesterol (Spitz and Hillbrand 1994) or serotonin (Brown, Goodwin, and Bunney 1982), high levels of testosterone ( MyMindField.com 2007), and even genetic disposition ( APAOnline 2007). A susceptibility to rage may also rest with one’s psychological profile. For instance, people with passive-aggressive personalities are prone to antagonistic verbal displays and may seek retribution for the slightest of perceived transgressions by other fans or stadium personnel (Stone 1993). Similarly, spectators with Type A personalities (i.e., highly competitive, intense achievement orientation) often allow their free-floating hostility to be triggered over minor incidents (Friedman 1996; Holmes and Will 1985). Even those with borderline personalities marked by feelings of low self-worth, obsessive behavior, and need for assurance can become aggressive and push others to act similarly (Mahari 2006).

A sport spectator’s propensity to rage may be attributable to powerful psychological factors as well. Consider the psychological phenomenon of identification, the process of maintaining a positive, self-defining relationship with others that one deems attractive (Kelman 1958, 1961). When sport fans consider their favorite team or athlete as an extension of their self (End et al. 2002; Kahle et al. 2001), their identification becomes a potentially intense psychological orientation, whereby individuals define themselves in terms of their attachment and derive strength and a sense of identity from the affiliation (Harris and Ogbonna 2008). When a strong link is formed between a spectator’s favorite sport teams/athletes and his or her self-concept (End et al. 2002; Hunt, Bristol, and Bashaw 1999), threats (e.g., losing, opponent’s fans, etc.) to the source of their self-concept (i.e., team/athlete) are taken personally. As a result, some fans become enraged in an effort to enhance their identity (Branscombe and Wann 1994) or as a defense strategy to restore self-esteem (Branscombe and Wann 1994; Wann et al. 2001; Wann, McLean, and Pullen 2003). While few services appear to provide a strong impetus for customer identification and self-concept enhancement as spectator sport, some examples do exist. Consider the strong brand community (Muniz and O’Guinn 2001) among the passionately loyal supporters of Nordstrom’s department stores and Southwest Airlines (Hart and Johnson 1999). While passionately loyal customers/fans are typically desired, services marketers should also recognize that avid patrons may also be more prone to rage when “their” retailers/teams underperform. Consider the anger and resentment expressed by loyal Netflix customers when the company announced rate changes to boost its revenue (Wortham and Stelter 2011). The influence of a fan’s physiological condition, psychological profile, and social identification on is illustrated in Figure 1 as customer temperament’s direct effect on rage.
Proposition 3: Fans’ propensity to rage becomes stronger when their (a) medical conditions energize their emotional state, (b) personality types are characterized by a desire to control their environment (e.g., Type A personalities), and/or (c) identification with the underperforming team is more intense.
Sociological factors may also influence a spectators’ inclination to rage. For instance, sport spectators often accept and identify with prescribed roles on how to behave at the sporting event (cf. Pratt and Cardador 2006) that may encourage aggressive behavior. One role typically assigned by the home team to its spectators is to foster a hostile environment for an opponent. For example, collegiate athletic stadiums are frequently branded with labels such as “Death Valley,” “The Pit,” and “The Swamp” and may serve as a reminder to home team fans that they are responsible for creating an intense, unwelcoming environment for opposing teams. In fact, a National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) official observed that “what becomes acceptable is to do your best to create an intimidating (home-field) atmosphere. And that has taken a toll on sportsmanship” (Weiberg 2002, p. 1). While the adversarial nature of fanatical sport spectators may appear somewhat unique, it is not totally unheard of in other service contexts. Expectations of confrontational roles often emerge or exist in retail encounters such as automobile purchase negotiations, themed restaurants like Dicks Last Resort, and services that involve tough-love personal interventions of various types.

The creation of a hostile home-field environment for an opponent may be intensified by a prevailing tradition of hostility that exists between the rival teams. For instance, antagonism between Croatians and Serbs is easily provoked due to their long history of mutual hatred. Similarly, fans of Scottish soccer rivals, Celtics and Glasgow Rangers, are often primed for action. The felt disdain for rival teams may exacerbate behaviors consistent with the rage-like fan role that include the creation of noise and the heckling or taunting of opponents and their supporters. In its extreme, there are spectators such as the “hooligans” who plague European soccer who have internalized the hostile fan role as part of a subculture identity (Hughson 1998). The sense of solidarity, excitement, and autonomy found in one’s affiliation with other like-minded fanatics facilitates an expression of boundless violence (i.e., hooliganism) directed at opponents (Spaaij 2008) and may provoke retaliatory responses from the hooligans’ targets. In a sense, then, aggression and its potential manifestation as spectator rage may be learned via socialization as appropriate behavior (Bandura 1973, 1986).

The social context associated with sport spectatorship is another sociological factor that may influence a spectator’s propensity to rage. More specifically, a spectator’s temperament for rage may result from a pronounced transformation that occurs when norms prescribing appropriate social behavior are suspended during sporting events in favor of a more egocentric view (Bredemeier, Shields, and Horn 1985). Hence, the social context of spectator sport may make it easy for some fans to replace the prescriptions of normally acceptable behavior in favor of a different set of norms that they believe define a “true fan.” For example, some spectators may believe that a “true fan” is expected to display passionate loyalty to the home team and hatred toward the opposition that, when overly intense or aggressive, may become rage. Similarly, group dynamics that commonly exist at sporting events may also contribute to the suspension of appropriate social behavior. All else being equal, social consequences for individuals’ actions are oftentimes less severe in large groups than when a person acts alone (Guerin 1994, 1998; Spaaij 2008). Accordingly, spectators may learn that the crowd at a sporting event provides a degree of anonymity which protects them from repercussions for hostile behavior (Wann, McLean, and Pullen 2003). Likewise, the collective excitement of the crowd at an event may intensify emotional responses among spectators making them more susceptible to rage behavior (Coakley 2008). Similar group dynamics may certainly occur at other service venues such as rock concerts and amusement parks, yet are not as common, nor likely to spawn behaviors as extreme.

The upshot of this discussion is that the social surroundings characterizing spectator sport and the marketing tactics directed at sport spectators within a group context may exacerbate the likelihood of rage by fostering a temperament for its expression. The influence of social (group)-related factors on rage is portrayed in Figure 1 by customer temperament’s direct effect on the phenomenon.
Proposition 4: Fans are increasingly prone to rage when they (a) take an active role in nurturing a “home-field” advantage through the creation of a hostile environment for the opposing team and/or (b) perceive that anonymity protects them from repercussions associated with hostile behavior.

sec.title: Triggers
sec.p:
Spectator and customer rage may be triggered by one or more factors that shape a fan’s/customer’s consumption experience (cf. de Rivera 1981; Shaver et al. 1987).When a spectator is exposed simultaneously to several energizing forces, their combination is likely to generate an even higher level of stimulation that leads to increasingly aggressive and potentially antisocial behaviors, including rage. Moreover, the strength of rage inducing triggers may be moderated by fan temperament, that is, the influence of the triggers may be stronger when one’s personality and/or current state of mind predisposes them to rage behavior. For instance, when a fan’s medical condition, personality type, or identification with a sport team/athlete heightens his or her emotional state it may also magnify the intensity of rage-inducing triggers. These observations are represented by Triggers’ direct effect (Proposition 5) and Temperament’s moderating influence on rage (Proposition 6) depicted in Figure 1.
Proposition 5: The interactive effect associated with a combining of energizing triggers is likely to increase a fan’s propensity to rage.
Proposition 6: A fan’s temperament may sensitize him or her to the energizing triggers and is likely to increase the propensity to rage.
The triggers of spectator and customer rage may be related to the nature of the consumption activity itself and/or situational factors present during a sporting event. The situational factors include five sets of influences posed by Belk (1975): The physical surroundings, social surroundings, task definition, temporal aspects, and antecedent states associated with one’s consumptive experience. These factors are likely to have a greater influence on the experiences of some spectators than others (cf. Bandura 1973). Examples of sport characteristics and situational forces that trigger spectator rage are discussed below as well as presented in Table 1 .

sec.title: The nature of the consumption activity
sec.p: The amount of suspense and/or aggressive behavior that characterizes a sporting event can evoke strong emotional responses from spectators. For instance, the suspense associated with the uncertainty of the outcome of a live sporting event can generate intense excitement (Madrigal 2004; Zillman 1996) and may turn to rage when a spectator witnesses the defeat of his or her favorite team, especially when the loss is to a hated rival (Zillman and Paulus 1993). Emotions may also be piqued by the degree of on field violence witnessed during a contest that may increase the likelihood that spectators will engage in aggressive behavior if they become frustrated or angry (Berkowitz 1993a). The nature of the consumption event’s influence on rage is portrayed in Figure 1 by Triggers’ direct effect on rage.

list-item.p: Proposition 7: Fans are prone to rage when (a) uncertainty of the contest’s outcome is distressing leading to frustration when it is unfavorable and/or (b) a contest is perceived as markedly aggressive and violent.

sec.title: Physical surroundings
sec.p: Conditions pertaining to the servicescape at the sport venue may contribute to a fan’s propensity to rage. Physical factors such as weather, the venue’s layout elevated sounds/noise level, cramped seating, and the like (cf, Belk 1975) may cause irritability that can ignite into rage. For instance, research has demonstrated that uncomfortably hot temperatures may lead to aggressive behavior (Anderson 2001; Bushman, Wang, and Anderson 2005) and excessive heat was recognized as one factor contributing to an intense brawl between Croatian and Serbian fans at an Australian Open Tennis Tournament (Sydney Morning Herald 2007).

One of the more scrutinized potential triggers of fan rage is the proximity of spectators to the athletic contest. Largely, a function of stadium design, the closer spectators are to the contest, the easier it is for them to become emotionally charged and to focus the release of their emotions toward the athletes. Consider an incident involving a fracas that erupted during a professional basketball contest between the Indiana Pacers and Detroit Pistons. The proximity of the fans to the action created a pronounced sense of game involvement and the opportunity for direct, physical interaction between spectators and players. Clearly, as with any servicescape, the spatial layout and functionality of the sport venue has the potential to influence fans’ actions (Bitner 1992).

Noise has also been linked to increased aggressive tendencies and physiological arousal (e.g., Geen and McCown 1984), yet it is often encouraged at sport venues to enhance the spectator experience and to serve as an intimidation factor for opponents of the home team. Promotional tactics such as dispensing noise-making devices to fans to create clatter or broadcasting video or audio messages that implore spectators to “make some noise” are frequent at many sporting events. It is also common for arenas to play loud music during intermissions and, increasingly, while a game is in progress. Furthermore, the lyrics of some of the broadcasted songs at arenas have been criticized for promoting and glamorizing hostility (Elmore 2004). Ironically, while these phenomena are meant to emotionally engage fans and enhance fans’ enjoyment of the sporting event, they may undermine it as well. While spectator sport is somewhat unique with respect to how it embraces noise, it is apparent that noise is a situational factor that can affect the likelihood of customer rage across diverse service contexts. The impact of an event’s physical surroundings on rage is depicted in Figure 1 by Triggers’ direct effect on rage.
Proposition 8: Fans are prone to rage when the physical surroundings of the venue (e.g., noise levels, close proximity to the field of play, uncomfortable temperatures, etc.) energize and/or irritate them.

sec.title: Social surroundings
sec.p: The number and social profile of those present at a sporting event, along with fans’ responsibilities and interpersonal interactions (Belk 1975), may affect the likelihood of rage. For example, crowded stadiums may trigger reactions of hostility. It is important to recognize that a distinction can be made between the phenomenon of crowding, an unpleasant feeling (Hui and Bateson 1991), and the related concept of density, the “spatial parameters” (Stokolos 1972) that characterize a servicescape. Sporting events are frequently marked by a high density of fans which may foster perceptions of crowding. Research suggests that discomfort, dissatisfaction, and negative feelings increase as the number of people in a service setting grows (Eroglu and Machleit 1990; Jackson and Latane 1982; Machleit, Eroglu, and Mantel 2000).

Density and the perception of crowding are a function of both the desire to maximize the number of seats available within a sport venue and to fill those seats with paying fans. While capacity crowds increases the potential for revenue generation and fan excitement at a sports venue, large crowds can also have adverse effects on fans’ experience that may result in incidents of rage. For example, increasing crowd density increases the likelihood of spectators bumping into another or accidentally spilling food or a beverage on others, which may prompt an aggressive response from the victim. Likewise, large crowds frequently create long queues at entry and exit gates, in concession areas and restrooms. Such queues may increase anxiety or stress and provide the opportunity for physical or verbal transgressions that can boost the probability of hostile behavior (Grove and Fisk 1997; Kumar, Kalwani, and Dada 1997).

Large crowds may also nurture the potential for fan rage by providing individuals with relative anonymity and deindividuation (Zimbardo 1970). Within spectator sport, this condition may lead some fans to lose their inhibitions about acting aggressively and feel unaccountable for their actions (Hirt and Clarkson 2011). The tendency for aggressive behavior may be exacerbated when there is an absence of visible authority figures at the venue. Security guards, law enforcement personnel, stadium staff, and the like operate as formal agents of social control 1 (Pfohl 1994) and their visible presence may be sufficient to reduce the probability of fan hostility. While the presence of authority figures is unlikely to curtail all expressions of rage, it may prompt one to reflect on the consequences of rage before he or she acts. Significant others (e.g., spouse, date and child) may perform a similar control function by informally inhibiting the likelihood of fan hostility due to the scorn, embarrassment, or rejection that might ensue (Goode 2007; Grove, Fisk, and John 2004).

Another social factor related to spectatorship that may lead to rage involves fan violations of unwritten rules regarding appropriate fan behavior. Typically, fans tend to abide by a common set of assumptions regarding the appropriate moments during a sporting event when conversation may take place, such as between plays (Melnick 1993). Similar assumptions apply to moving to and from one’s seat. For instance, during a professional tennis match, fans normally are not allowed to relocate to their seats between or during points. In addition, fans are expected to allow other spectators a clear line of sight while the action is in progress and to move quickly out of the line of sight of other spectators when relocating to or from their seats. If these rules are not honored an offended fan’s viewing experience is interrupted and he or she may become irritated, resulting in anger and rage. To be sure, negative aspects of crowding may have a similar effect across other services as well, yet, when crowding is coupled with other situational variables (e.g., noise) present at sport venues, its impact is greatly enhanced. Proposition 9: Fans are prone to rage when (a) there is discomfort due to crowding; (b) a perceived absence of authority; and/or (c) inappropriate spectatorship behaviors by others.

sec.title: Task definition/spectator motives
sec.p: Frustration-Aggression Theory, a broad explanation for aggressive behavior in general, posits that people may exhibit violent tendencies when they are blocked from achieving certain goals (Berkowitz 1993b). Correspondingly, spectator rage may arise when fans perceive that they are unduly blocked from fulfilling their spectator roles, referred to as task definitions (Belk 1975), or from realizing their spectator motives (Shaver et al. 1987). Fans engage in spectatorship for a variety of reasons such as a desire to be entertained; to be aroused and excited; or, to escape from the stresses of everyday life (Hirt and Clarkson 2011). Fans may also engage in spectatorship to rid themselves of negative/detrimental emotions and tensions; to display positive emotions; to provide a forum for self-expression through identification with a team or athlete; to display pride in the city/place that is home to their favorite teams/athletes and, to promote social bonding with other fans who share a common interest and enthusiasm (Grove, Dorsch, and Hopkins 2012).

The likelihood of aggressive behavior increases when excessively engaged fans are unable to realize their spectatorships goals (Wann et al. 2001). For instance, fans may believe that the athletic performance is not as entertaining as they had hoped or falls below typical standards. Fans may also show their displeasure when a contest fails to display the amount of aggressiveness they desired. For example, hockey fans sometimes show their displeasure with the entertainment value of a lackluster contest by chanting “More fights, less hockey.” In other situations, highly identified fans may become enraged when they witness a loss by their favorite team. More specifically, whereas fans with a weak team attachment may engage in CORFing—a process of cutting off reflected failure—in an attempt to protect their self-esteem following their team’s loss, highly identified fans tend to avoid CORFing since it is akin to devaluating the self (Wann and Branscombe 1990). As a sport team/athlete becomes an important part of a fan’s self-concept, it is more difficult for the fan to distance himself or herself from the team’s outcomes/ performances (Hirt and Clarkson 2011), and it is more likely that the fan will express anger and rage when the contest outcome is negative.

Spectatorship motives of excessively engaged fans may induce rage. For instance, consider the highly publicized incidents involving European football fans who trek to away games and support their team by aggressively challenging their counterparts. Taunts, chants, and other negative behaviors that are perceived by some spectators as a part of an ardent fan’s role can also incite hostility from the opposition. In addition, similar to consumers of other types of hedonic consumption, sport spectators, tend to create and act upon a subjective reality that may not be congruent with objective reality (Hirschman and Holbrook 1982). Shaver et al. (1987) found that individuals exhibit cognitive biases and distortions when describing personal experiences that tend to extol the appropriateness of their own positions. Hence, when fans become absorbed with escaping their daily lives, they may create a subjective reality that enables them to flee the rules/norms that normally govern them and redefine aggressive and antisocial behaviors as appropriate. Escaping reality in such a manner may explain why some fans of winning teams physically and/or verbally abuse fans of the losing opposition.

The significance fans place on a contest may also increase their likelihood of rage. When fans are intensely focused on the outcome of a contest, the strong psychological tie between spectators and their favored team may pique tensions and anxieties when the desired outcome is in jeopardy. Sport rivalries involving local teams (e.g., New York Yankees and Boston Red Sox) or national sides (e.g., India and Pakistan cricket teams) may be particularly vulnerable to such behavior. When organizers and the media aggressively promote heated competitive rivalries and key events (e.g., championship games and geographic rivalries), some fans may place a heightened importance on the contest’s outcome. In these instances, the “win or die” or “there’s no tomorrow” meaning that emerges may stokes fans’ passion and propensity to rage.

From a task definition perspective, the sporting event may be important to some spectators for other nonsport reasons. Consider the case of gambling. Placing a bet on an athletic contest obviously increases its significance to the bettor. Hence, it not surprising that studies indicate gamblers may be more likely to engage in acts of rage—particularly if one should lose his or her wager (Parke and Griffiths 2004). Despite the link between hostile behavior and gambling, many sport organizations have relaxed policies which in the past restricted the formation of relationships with gambling entities (McKelvey 2004). The upshot of this is that the importance one assigns to a service encounter—whether it is an anticipated vacation, the repair of one’s cherished automobile, or the outcome of an athletic contest against a hated foe—may increase the possibility of rage. Proposition 10: Fans are prone to rage when they (a) find it difficult to realize their spectatorship motives and/or (b) are dominated by a desire to accomplish them.

sec.title: Temporal perspective
sec.p: Sometimes the time-based issues surrounding a consumptive activity (Belk 1975) may induce customer frustration/anxiety that can lead to rage. When examined from a temporal perspective, crowding and lengthy queues may create exasperatingly long waits for fans that keep them from realizing various objectives (e.g., watching the live sporting event), ultimately causing irritability and anxiety—two states that may ignite rage. This is particularly so when fans feel as if little progress is being made toward their goal of entering or leaving the stadium, acquiring refreshments, or gaining access to the restroom (Haynes 1990). Likewise, fan perceptions of being hurried or rushed may also create an ill temper. Hence, similar to customers in general, fans who feel they are being herded in or out of a venue at a pace not to their liking may react in an abusive fashion.

As a situational variable, time may contribute to the likelihood of spectator rage in other ways as well. For instance, the amount of time that has (or has not) transpired between infractions by the opposing team, how long it has been since one team has been victorious against a foe, or the time pressure a fan may feel as a result of a contest lasting too long may create a heightened emotional state that renders one rage ready. In short, how time is experienced by spectators (and service customers as a whole) may contribute to one’s ire. The Temporal aspects’ impact on rage is illustrated in Figure 1 by Triggers’’ direct effect on rage.
Proposition 11: Fans are prone to rage when they perceive an inappropriate amount of time has elapsed associated with some aspect of the spectator experience.

sec.title: Antecedent states
sec.p: Antecedent states, such as momentary moods or temporary conditions that customers or spectators experience prior to engaging in consumption, establishes a context which may influence customers’ consumption experience (Belk 1975) and their likelihood to rage. Moods may influence or be influenced by one’s consumption experience (Gardner 1985; Knowles, Grove, and Pickett 1993) and spectators whose moods prior to a sporting event reflect feelings of being anxious, frustrated, highly energized, or aggressive are prime candidates to rage. For example, spectators may become frustrated by unexpected traffic delays in arriving at the stadium; failure to bring an item that enhances the spectatorship experience (e.g., binoculars, seating cushion); or, receiving unpleasant news unrelated to the sporting event. Other conditions that can affect fan mood and influence rage may be traced to a sport venue’s marketing practices or policies such as those that ban certain personal possessions (e.g., umbrellas, beverage coolers, etc.) from the venue.

As an antecedent state, a temporary mental state resulting from alcohol consumption is perhaps the most common trigger of spectator rage. When used as a means to escape or to ostensibly enhance one’s experience, alcohol consumption may exacerbate the impact of other triggers present at a sporting event. Alcohol is intricately linked to spectator sport in general. It is frequently a key aspect of pregame rituals such as “tailgating” as well as postgame celebrations or commensurations. Further, alcohol is commonly sold inside the venue, allowing fans to continue imbibing during an event. According to one estimate, nearly 10% of the males leaving a major league baseball game are legally drunk (O’Brien and Hersch 1998). A number of studies show that alcohol increases the likelihood of aggressive behavior (e.g., Bushman and Cooper 1990), particularly for those with antisocial personality disorder (Moeller and Dougherty 2001). There is even some evidence that the mere image of alcohol can evoke aggressive tendencies (Bartholow and Heinz 2006), raising questions about advertising of alcohol outside of or within sporting venues.

While other triggers of customer rage exist, the preceding discussion and examples provided in Table 1 point to broad categories of factors that may prompt spectators to lash out at other fans, workers, sport participants, the sport setting, or even the athletic performance itself. Moreover, these factors often operate in combination (e.g., crowded circumstances, loud noises, and excessive alcohol consumption) to create a service environment that is more conducive for acts of aggression and rage. Proposition 12: Fans are prone toward rage when they experience unexpected and temporary factors that have an adverse influence on their moods.

sec.title: Treatments
sec.p: Sport marketers may employ various tactics to reduce fans’ proneness to rage and address those incidences when rage occurs. In many ways, these treatments reflect efforts to manage customer compatibility in service contexts in general (Martin and Pranter 1989) and suggest initiatives that could be applied to services at large. For example, adopting Lovelock and Wirtz’s (2011) three-stage model of service consumption, one way to approach treatment options is to consider actions that an organization might take before, during, and after an event. Clearly, the result of any pregame planning will be evident during a contest, yet we categorize activities based on when the substantive work required to address rage incidents is likely to occur. Regardless, the foci of the treatments are the Triggers, Temperament, and Targets, separately or in combination (see Figure 1) and involve endeavors that are typically directed at one or more the four components of the service encounter—customers, employees, service setting, or service process (Fisk, Grove, and John 2008).

sec.title: Pregame treatments
sec.p: Role definition: Perhaps, the best opportunity to address temperament characteristics that influence spectator rage is prior to the service encounter. This endeavor may involve customer socialization similar to the approaches used to educate patrons of any service. In the context of sport, these tactics include the efforts of leagues or other governing bodies that prescribe spectator roles that reflect good sportsmanship. Recently, the NFL defined the boundaries of appropriate and inappropriate fan behavior through publication of its “Fan Code of Conduct” (McCarthy 2008). This guide addresses a broad cross section of unacceptable fan action including intoxication, disruptive behavior, foul language, obscene gestures, game interference, and verbal harassment of opposing team fans. Similarly, a Florida youth baseball organization was recognized as a model for educating parents and spectators regarding appropriate fan behavior. The organization annually packs more than 1,500 parents into a stadium to watch a video concerning how to be a good sports parent, to provide a handbook describing sportsmanship, and to sign a sportsmanship pledge (Cary, Dotinga, and Comarow 2004). In a related effort, the NCAA has held sportsmanship summits where coaches and athletic administrators discuss ideas for curbing violence (Brown 2003). Some of the recommendations include encouraging staff from opposing teams to participate in pregame planning activities and to meet with key student groups before/during the season to review consequences of rage behavior. These and similar campaigns introduce alternatives to the hostile role assumed by many spectators by educating the fans and imparting appropriate behavior.

Repositioning the sport brand: It may be possible to position a sport brand to encourage civil behavior. A sport enterprise that emphasizes responsible competition and a positive experience should motivate spectators to exhibit those properties as well. Moreover, hostility toward opposing fans or other targets as a means of restoring self-esteem when poor performances occur should diminish as an acceptable defense mechanism. For example, Clemson University’s athletic department initiated a campaign in recent years to emphasize the message “our actions honor our university, traditions, teams, performance, people and each other” (Match 2007). The message is communicated through a variety of media before entering the sport venues, as well as once fans are seated via signage and in-game announcements. Hence, building and reinforcing a sport organization’s brand image that stresses positive attributes of sportsmanship and is void of elements that undermine it may curb the likelihood of spectator rage.

Information provision:. Beyond the broad efforts to promote civil behavior, pregame planning should focus on informing patrons of specific behaviors that are considered inappropriate and subject to disciplinary sanctions. Teams often list actionable offenses on the backside of game tickets and in promotional materials sent to ticket purchasers. In addition, reminders about appropriate fan behaviors are announced prior to the beginning of a competitive event via signage and other forms of messaging. Sponsors might also help reduce the potential for poor fan behavior by closely scrutinizing the nature of items distributed to fans as part of their sponsorship activities. Giveaway such as key chains with team logos or miniature baseball bats can become projectiles or weapons for unruly fans.

sec.title: Game-day treatments
sec.p: Spectator screening: Pregame planning for fan rage may involve implementing policies and practices that minimize fan access to the targets of rage and eliminate or reduce the influence of potential rage triggers. While such tactics may require considerable circumspection prior to an event, they are essentially initiated at the outset of the service encounter or sport contest. For example, spectators attending an event are commonly confronted with security personnel as they enter the facility. Beyond ticket validation, the opportunity exists to screen spectators prior to granting entrance for banned items (e.g., alcohol, noise makers, projectiles, weapons/ fireworks, and lasers) that could trigger or be used in episodes of rage. The NFL, for instance, maintains a policy requiring teams to establish a screening process that subjects fans to the possibility of a random search. While the policy has received legal scrutiny as a violation of one’s protection from unreasonable search (Nagel 2005; Varian 2005), U.S. courts rejected the contention clearing the way for other organizations to follow the precedence (Washington Post 2007).

Event security: Inside the servicescape, most sporting events are staffed by security and law enforcement whose presence is intended to deter acts of aggression and enforce stadium policies regarding breaches of acceptable behavior. After all, one role that the service marketer must play to prompt customer adherence to rules is that of the police officer (Lovelock 1981). Spectators engaging in objectionable acts are typically removed from a venue and if their rage behavior is criminal in nature they may face charges from local or state authorities. In fact, the NFL’s recently endorsed a fan policy in which poor behavior from a season ticketholder’s guest can result in the loss of season ticket rights for the ticket owner (McCarthy 2008). More recently, some sport organizations have adopted technologies to assist them in the identification of fans engaging in hostile behavior. Monitoring systems (e.g., closed-circuit cameras), including those that may require considerable pregame planning, are often used to ensure effective coverage of potential trouble locations. Such systems have aided various professional teams attempting to identify disruptive spectators and are now mandatory for all Greek and Italian professional soccer stadiums (Kitsantonis 2007; Sanminiatelli 2007).

Another technology-driven means to address incidence of unruly spectators involves the use of dedicated mobile telephone numbers that allow fans to report disruptive behavior of others in real time and relative anonymity to appropriate security officials. Such efforts can enhance the efficiency of a security force by allowing them to better target their actions. Empowering fans through technology can also minimize their feelings of helplessness and isolation while helping organizations to respond to inappropriate spectator behavior.

Alcohol restrictions: Other game-day strategies might attempt to minimize the influence of alcohol as a potential trigger for hostility. For example, the NCAA prohibits the sale of alcoholic beverages in on-campus athletic facilities. Further, some universities place restrictions on “pass-outs” (a term referring to the practice of allowing spectators to exit and reenter the stadium), which are often used by some fans as an opportunity to consume more alcohol. Other institutions are taking a more hard line approach to curbing the negative effect of alcohol consumption by restricting or banning alcoholic beverages in the parking lots outside of stadiums. Given the strong link between alcohol consumption and spectator sports, such policies are often met with considerable resistance, yet are also likely to reduce the incidence of spectator rage.

Strict restrictions are also placed on the sale of alcohol during athletic events. For instance, beer sale inside stadiums is often terminated at a designated time well before a game’s scheduled conclusion. In fact, during a 2005 contest, the New York Jets and the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority (facility owners) agreed to ban the sale of alcohol inside the stadium for an entire game to reduce the likelihood of hostilities during the event carrying over from a previous meeting of the opposing teams. Relatedly, to minimize the potential of fan rage outside of their stadium, the Chicago Bears have removed tailgaters from the parking lots at Soldier Field at kick-off if they fail to produce a ticket to the scheduled game (Bonk 2008).

Seating assignments: By thoughtfully considering the spatial functionality and layout of the servicescape (Bitner 1992), a variety of seating options may be developed that allow logical fan segmentation (i.e., students, opposing fans, etc.) to quell the likelihood of rage. Through ticket distribution, spectators with the potential to be targets or initiators of rage may be assigned seating with additional security and/or monitoring. A feature common in many European soccer stadiums is special fencing around sections designated for fans of the visiting team. In addition, many sports venues offer family sections inside the stadium which are “free from alcohol sales, exposure to alcohol, and foul, suggestive or vulgar language” (Seattle Seahawks 2007). By creating advance seat selection processes, seating options that mitigate frustrations at an event that contribute to aggressive feelings and displays of inappropriate behavior are possible.

Queuing methods: Service providers have long recognized the importance of managing wait times to improve customers’ service experience (e.g. Hui and Tse 1996; McGuire and Kimes 2006; Rafaeli, Barron, and Haber 2002). Haynes (1990) offers a number of waiting guidelines that are applicable in a sport setting. For instance, concession or restroom waits might seem shorter if sport venues provide fans closed-circuit viewing or audio broadcasting of the action they are missing to counter the perception that “empty minutes are long minutes.” Additionally, offering creative concession options such as single-item purchase lines, special queues for popular items, or employing technology that enables in-seat purchases may prove efficient and equitable. When waiting is unavoidable, efforts could be made to make customer/fan wait time as comfortable as possible. For instance, during extremely hot outdoor events positioning a fan/air conditioner or a misting system to cool those in line might lessen spectators’ angst.

Random acts of kindness: Like customers in general, most fans arguably want a congenial environment where they feel safe and where their basic needs are supported by the hosting organization. In that regard, simple acts of kindness such as making water or a personal cooling system (e.g., a hand-held fan) freely available to spectators on hot days might create feelings of goodwill that alleviates sour moods, reduces anxiety, and ultimately creates a more enjoyable atmosphere. Similarly, a venue could employ goodwill ambassadors who would patrol the stands to assist patrons with small gestures of kindness, which might change the temperament of some fans and reduce the potential for rage behavior.

sec.title: Postgame treatments
sec.p: Fines and sanctions: Increasingly, sport organizations address incidents of spectator rage by imposing significant financial penalties for failure to enforce security policies. For example, in 2005, the international governing body for soccer (Federation Internationale de Football Association) fined three national clubs “for lack of proper security arrangements for that match” (CNN.com 2005). Similarly, the Italian Soccer Federation passed several “zero tolerance” rules intended to curb fan violence at soccer matches, including cancelling a game at any time should violence erupt inside or outside of the stadium or if offensive signs, banners, or symbols are seen inside the venue (Associated Press 2005). While these actions are punitive in nature, they vividly underscore the link between fan misbehavior and measures that have been developed to address it.

Video review: Information regarding significant incidents of spectator rage should be collected, catalogued, and reviewed following every sporting event. A system can be developed wherein officials who witness rage are required to file a written report detailing the incident from their perspective. Such feedback can be aggregated and examined for trends and patterns. Accounts of rage episodes can be submitted by hand-written reports or via technology (e.g., video cameras). For example, during the mid-1990s, the NFL’s New England Patriots used the footage from cameras mounted inside its stadium to identify spectators engaging in inappropriate behavior. During the camera surveillance system’s first year in use, a total of 70 season ticket holders were refused requests to renew their tickets due to violations of the team policies (Weisman 1995).

Service recovery: Management can review “critical rage incidents” to determine if the spectator/spectators were principally at fault or if the organization/service employee/employees played an instrumental role in triggering hostile action. If the right type of information is collected, the sport organization may be afforded an opportunity to engage in service recovery for innocent parties and bystanders who were significantly impacted by the rage event. In addition, employee training and incentive programs might be developed that emphasize effective management of service failure and customer rage incidents (Grove, Fisk, and John 2004). Finally, using the postgame information, sport venues can embrace an organizational learning perspective that welcomes process review and improvement through regular and systematic examination of collected accounts.
