Proposition 13: Fans are less prone to rage when (a) they are aware that their behavior is being monitored and accountable for their actions and/or (b) the venue effectively manages fan experiences before, during, and after an event to disarm aggressive behavior.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: As services marketers continue to explore ways to emotionally engage customers, the possibility exists that those efforts may result in unexpected and unfavorable customer reactions. Customer rage is a complex and potentially disruptive response that emotionally charged patrons may exhibit as a reaction to extreme irritation and/or frustration created by a variety of interactive elements present in many service encounters. Through an application of the 4-Ts of Customer Rage framework, sport marketers might better understand the circumstances that intensify one’s propensity to rage and potential treatments to address its occurrence. As related here, many of the variables leading to combustible situations within a sport context can be anticipated and managed before, during and after rage’s occurrence. In fact, many sport organizations are currently mobilizing to deal more effectively with rage’s detrimental circumstances. We hope that by bringing attention to and applying the 4-Ts of customer rage, sport practitioners are provided a valuable tool in their quest to create a more positive fan experience.

One of the hallmarks of the service sector is duality of the uniqueness of the industries that comprise it and the commonality among them. Service firms that study organizations confronting similar problems in other service industries can learn from them (Lovelock 1994). Hence, by investigating spectator rage, services marketers in general may glean insights regarding rage behavior that apply to their industry. Our framework suggests that when services emotionally engage their customers, rage can occur even when the service is performed properly and without failure. This can happen when customers personalize the service encounter and experience obstructions in accomplishing their consumptive goals due to factors unrelated to actual service performance (Prahalad and Ramaswamy 2006). Even when organizations customize their service delivery (Lovelock 1983), the possibility exists that some customers may still exhibit different and contradictory responses (cf, Hirschman and Holbrook 1982). Moreover, when services emotionally engage their customers, the potential for customer rage increases; this is especially true when patrons become highly stimulated and experience frustrations/interruptions that affect their goal-oriented behavior (cf, de Rivera 1981; Shaver et al. 1987).

Evidence presented here suggests that rage also results from individual traits inherent among some customers, situational variables found in many service encounters, and conditions that may be created as part of an organizations’ marketing effort. Understanding that these factors may interact to produce rage events should help organizations plan and manage inappropriate behavior. For example, airlines today aggressively screen passengers and have established elaborate procedures to identify the most threatening customers. Unfortunately, other practices such as ignoring seat assignments which fliers “reserved” when purchasing their ticket or charging passengers a fee for basic accommodations such as a beverage or a pillow and blanket may foster disdain that percolates into fury. “Acts of kindness” in these service delivery decisions can set a tone of civility and hospitality to enhance positive mood states rather than prompting negative responses.

Our framework acknowledges that sport marketers may be unable to completely eliminate fan rage; instead, we offer suggestions for reducing its likelihood that are also applicable to services in general. For example, during the service design process, marketers might identify those moments of truth that are expected to generate emotional highs and/or lows for customers. The creation of certain strong emotions (e.g., pleasure and excitement) may be part of the service experience design, while others (e.g., aggressiveness, anxiety, and anger) are likely to be unintended. Recognizing that both emotional responses are possible, service design should include discussions/blueprinting that identify experiential factors that evoke strong emotional reactions, whether intended or unintended, favorable or unfavorable (cf, Haeckel, Carbone, and Berry 2003). When a moment-of-truth that increases one’s proneness to rage is ascertained, the service can be redesigned to incorporate experience-related elements that are meant to diffuse/reduce anger-related tendencies (e.g., warning/cautioning customers about becoming overly emotional prior to and upon completion of their service experience, visible signage or other communications that reminds customers to engage in pro-social behaviors, observable security, etc.). Additionally, customers can be monitored during the service performance to identify problems and conduct “experience intervention” to keep emotionally charged customers from becoming enraged. Experience interventions may require a patron to be removed from the stimulating environment in order to calm him or her down (essentially, putting the customer in an “emotional time-out”). In other situations, the customer may be detained and required to provide retribution for injuring others or damaging property while in the highly charged emotional state.

Service organizations such as large retailers, amusement venues, and others might learn from sport marketers how to better manage anticipated overcrowding situations that sometimes occur in conjunction with special shopping days and events. Just as sport venues utilize a season ticket process and point systems to allocate scarce seating capacity, other services might anticipate capacity shortages and better manage the process of queuing customer demand through allocation of desired scarce goods or services well in advance of a heavy shopping day. Such a system would be valuable to assuage potential rage events that might occur on “Black Friday” when shoppers are in pursuit of the newest digital device that is in short supply. Crowded entertainment settings, such as theme parks and concerts, could certainly benefit from nearly all of the treatments suggested within the sport context. From security planning and execution to seating arrangements to information provision and screening systems, directives that reflect how sport venues address these considerations could be studied and applied to reduce the potential for rage events in other service contexts. For example, sports venue practices regarding scheduling and placing security personnel/surveillance, physically segregating customers within the servicescape who may not get along well with each other, and denying entrance or re-entrance into the service establishment could be adopted to quell rage in other service contexts.

It is important to recognize that two distinct considerations exist for the effective management of rage, whether the efforts involve spectator sport or other service types: (a) the degree to which marketers are able to address the features that render a service encounter susceptible to rage and (b) the extent to which potential treatments for rage conflict with marketing objectives. Some of the factors that enhance the opportunity for rage may be addressed while others may not. In general, circumstances that pass for the triggers of rage offer a greater potential for control and treatment. To a large degree, trigger conditions are traceable to a distinct cause-and-effect relationship that might be minimized by organizational action. As noted, organizations could create a less volatile servicescape by communicating appropriate and inappropriate behavior to customers, using systems and technology to reduce long queues, branding the service experience to embrace civil behavior and discourse, attending to controllable situational factors that have the potential to diminish customer frustration (such as lowering the music volume or minimizing crowding), and curtailing alcohol sales (where applicable).

Slightly less treatable are those service aspects linked to the target category of rage factors. Targets of rage are often requisite parts of the service encounter that cannot be removed without altering the essence of the experience itself. Customers, front-stage employees, and other support personnel that may become targets of rage are integral elements of many service experiences (Booms and Bitner 1981). In sport, the potential targets of rage include the fans, players, officials, and coaches. While efforts by services marketers to manage customer compatibility can reduce the likelihood of rage (Grove and Fisk 1997; Martin and Pranter 1989), it is difficult to completely eliminate its rapid and spontaneous expression. Nevertheless, services marketing efforts that center on designing/managing the servicescape to preempt incidents of fan rage and limit customer access to targets might be pursued. For instance, the ambient conditions (e.g., noise level and air temperature), signs, symbols and artifacts (e.g., video communications and audio announcements), and space/function (e.g., seating arrangements, capacity expansions, and queuing processes) are elements that can be addressed in spectator sport and other service contexts (Bitner 1992). Arguably, the same facility features that many organizations incorporate to create a high degree of interaction and intimacy with their customers may also increase the potential or opportunity for rage and require careful scrutiny.

The least addressable set of factors contributing to rage reside in the temperament category. Knowing that some people may be predisposed to rage incidents is certainly unsettling. Ultimately, the enduring personality characteristics and less obvious physical and social conditions that comprise a customer’s temperament can only be managed when employees are trained to monitor and recognize the inappropriate behavior that temperament manifests. Thus, preemptive actions necessary to screen for potential disruptive customers are very difficult and offer the least opportunity for treatment options.

Ironically, there may be no service industry other than spectator sport where an organization’s interest in reducing or eliminating acts of aggressive behavior conflict more directly with the organizational objectives assigned to marketers. Sport marketers are charged with providing spectators with an engaging and exciting entertainment experience, yet many of the practices used to create an emotionally arousing and profitable experience (e.g., availability of alcohol, a loud and electrifying atmosphere, the criticality of a contest, etc.) may also trigger fan rage. For example, the availability and promotion of alcoholic is largely based on the fact that sales of it represent a substantial revenue stream for many sport organizations (Wann et al. 2001) and devices such as “thunder sticks” (inflatable noise-making plastic balloons), given to spectators at an event are typically emblazoned with sponsor logos. Further, promoting contests as rivalries, “big games” and “do-or-die” situations may stir emotions among patrons that simultaneously piques fan interest and the likelihood of aggressive behavior; such contests may enhance revenue through premium ticket pricing, media rights, and sponsorship fees, yet carry a cost in terms of spectator rage. In short, efforts to emotionally energize fans can go awry when they generate a response that nudges them beyond rage’s “boiling point” (Grove, Fisk, and John 2004).

While the focus of this article examines the deleterious effects of fan and customer rage, it bears noting that there may also be an upside to the phenomenon. As paradoxical as it may seem, dysfunctional customer behavior such as the incidence of spectator rage may foster manifest and/or latent positive outcomes as well (Fisk et al. 2010). For example, rage’s occurrence creates an obvious need for personnel to monitor and address incidents of hostility that can manifest itself as employment opportunities or the development of innovative surveillance systems and technology. At the very least, rage’s repeated incidence signals the need for change in handling spectator participation at the sport venue. Furthermore, latent benefits ensuing from fan rage may exist that include an affirmation of the ideal spectator role through a contrast effect with the role embodied by the misbehaving fan, or a growth in the study of and education about rage phenomena that contributes to behavioral knowledge in general. Clearly, other positive outcomes might be identified when carefully considering the occurrence of spectator rage.

It is also possible that some of the rage treatments found in sport and other service enterprises favorably impact customer satisfaction and revenue. For example, customers are sometimes willing to pay a premium for access to family only seating sections in sport venues or to become a favored customer with special membership access to organizational services and information. Similarly, improved queuing methods and various amenities (e.g., fans, heaters, spacious aisles, and restrooms) at a service site may improve customers’ experience and the likelihood of future patronage. In addition, efforts to improve security may deter vandalism against facility features, thereby reducing maintenance costs while enhancing the servicescape overall.

sec.title: Future Research Directions
sec.p: The research propositions posed in the article identify various factors linked to the likelihood of dissatisfying service encounters that may explode into rage filled episodes and provide direction for empirical research into the phenomenon of customer rage. Additional rage-related research should explore some very basic issues that are pertinent to service practitioners. Beyond the societal costs associated with raging customers, other costs exist. For instance, research is needed to monetize the financial costs associated with rage incidents in terms of the outlay needed to manage rage and the lower revenue potential that may result from its occurrence. In general, studies that assess the size and scope of the impact of rage on a firm’s bottom line are desirable.

Also needed is research that examines the strength of the potential triggers of rage incidents, whether it is fan rage or rage associated with some other type of service. At what point might single rage intensifiers reach a threshold prompting customer action detrimental to the service enterprise? In what combination are triggers most potent and is it worth the expense to reduce or lock down some triggers and not others? Efforts that examine the potency of various rage triggers and the extent to which they reside in different sports and/or service industries might help pinpoint those most susceptible to rage. In this respect, service blueprints that identify rage fail points might be developed as tools to aid practitioners by clarifying where money should be allocated to curtail rage,s incidence, for example, increasing the presence of security personnel, developing proactive messaging to promote appropriate customer behavior, or servicescape redesign to alleviate long queues or frustrating waits.

Other investigations should examine how rage impacts employee and customer satisfaction and the service’s brand’ image, as well as study the effect specific recovery programs have on dealing with the aftermath of rage incidents. For instance, while enraged customers are likely to perceive the encounter in a less positive light, how does a rage incident impact the perceptions of other customers who witnessed the episode? Are there sustained consequences affecting future patronage patterns or negative word of mouth? Such information is desirable as a critical first step in designing recovery systems that minimize long-term damage to the sport or service enterprise.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Spectator rage is a complex phenomenon that shares some common underpinnings with customer rage in general and possesses some aspects that are unique to spectator sport. The occurrence of rage in any specific service type is likely to be comprised of shared and unique features that pose a myriad of challenges for those concerned with the deleterious consequences of aggressive patron behavior. However, for service encounters that create an emotional connection with the customer, it may be impractical (if not impossible) for organizations to completely eliminate hostile behavior from the customer experience; this is certainly true with respect to spectator sport. In those situations, organizations are faced with difficult decisions regarding what can be done to control the potential for rage and what should be done to control it while still preserving the essence of the interactive service experience. In the preceding pages, the 4-Ts of Customer Rage framework was employed to systematically categorize and examine these issues with respect to spectator sport to enhance our knowledge of both fan rage and customer rage at large. While specific solutions for managing the incidence of rage are likely to be driven by the resources and needs of each organization individually, we believe that organizations can benefit from a comprehensive plan of attack that we hope our treatment may facilitate.

fn.p: While not a subject of this discussion, it bears noting that security personnel at sport venues may also be a Target of rage. For example, a number of recent incidents at Italian soccer matches have been attributed to conflict between Italian youth and police. In such instances, the sporting event provides a vehicle for the expression of rage toward social concerns, political issues, or the like.
